transcript.text: What do competition laws prohibit? Click on each reveal button to learn more.

contentText.text: Competition laws prohibit agreements between competitors that have an effect on price or that limit customer choice.

instructionText.text: Click on each reveal button to learn more. You may need to scroll to read the full answer.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

popText.text: Price fixing is an agreement by two or more competitors to set prices for goods or services. These agreements are always illegal.

Price fixing occurs if you and a competitor agree to:
  • hold prices firm
  • adopt a known formula for computing prices
  • stick to a minimum-fee or price schedule
  • eliminate or reduce discounts
Bid rigging is an agreement by two or more competitors where they predetermine which competitor will win a specific bid or tender.

Bid rigging occurs if you and a competitor agree to:
  • not bid or to withdraw from an already-submitted bid so that the competitor’s (or your) bid will win
  • submit bids that are intentionally too high to win, but give the appearance of being legitimate – the bids are not submitted to win, they are submitted to lose so that your competitor wins as prearranged
  • submit bids, but take turns being the low bidder

flipCard.buttonImg: Competitors agreeing not to deal with a specific supplier

popText.text: Group boycotts are an agreement by two or more competitors to refuse to deal with a specific supplier or customer in order to discipline, punish or otherwise damage the supplier or customer for its actions.
Group boycotts occur if you and a competitor agree not to work with a specific customer as a punishment for that customer choosing another competitor for a prior big project.
Market allocation is an agreement by two or more competitors to divide customers or markets.

Market allocation could happen if you and a competitor agree to work with specific customers, e.g.:
  • “I take customer A, you take customer B”
  • “I take customers in the North, you take customers in the South”
Antitrust or competition law violations require an “agreement,” but what does that mean?
An agreement does not have to be put in writing to break the law. It could be a verbal agreement. In fact, a concerted practice or pattern of behavior is enough to be classified as agreement.
